# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a solution using the Julia programming language:

```julia
using DataFrames, DataFramesMeta

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df = @where(df, manufacturer .== "audi")
    df[:audi_a4_type] = @map(df, model) do m
        if lowercase(m) in ["a4", "a4 quattro"]
            true
        else
            false
        end
    end
    return df
end
```
This function first filters the DataFrame `df` to only include rows where the manufacturer is "audi" using `@where`. Then it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` for all rows in which the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro", and `false` otherwise. This is done with `@map` and an anonymous function, which checks if each model name (converted to lowercase) is either "a4" or "a4 quattro".

You can use this function as follows:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
                   model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
